title: Elementary – Cycle 3 – Progression of Learning - English as a Second Language (2009)
subject: Languages

document.title: Elementary – Cycle 3 – Progression of Learning - English as a Second Language (2009)

907E55705FBC449CB9BD616E649918A1.description: Idiomatic expressions (e.g. Break a leg. That rings a bell. Cat got her tongue.)

51E88E377579405380D92B834F759ACE.description: Traditions related to celebrations and special events (e.g. birthdays, Christmas, Earth Day)

3694C3F9811B4B5CB5C40BC6B1883E4B.description: Origin of names (e.g. family names, businesses)

69BAFEEAC5DD41A7B325032FEDF95DB5.description: Texts, media, games (e.g. films, magazines, Web sites)

E7DB309F1F5C407C859766B03DC948EF.description: Identifies and briefly describes characters, people, animals, objects, place and setting

2C2DF7C4363848CE98D18B754D4D4601.description: Identifies general ideas stated explicitly (i.e. literal meaning

D2A37834BEA9435DA42B3D20777F1545.description: Uses contextual cues to construct meaning

5D080F79DCEB4B98A223D586788B46E0.description: Uses contextual cues to recognize a variety of text formats (e.g. newspaper article, graphic novel, advertisement) and to predict content

AC542A07E6484A368E4DC8CD65D8451F.description: Contextual cues: titles, subtitles, synopsis, key sentences, illustrations, table of contents

1212099EC52746379AA1B3199857BD81.description: Uses knowledge of connecting words to construct meaning

93D9916F0980406C9F8AB67FD19918F2.description: Connecting words (e.g. once upon a time, next, finally)

E2A73AD86654410898819AA55954E733.description: Spells words as found in open-ended models and available resources targeted for carrying out tasks

77F245A90E7D4A25A94E9B40AC747FED.description: Spells words as found in explicit models and resources targeted for carrying out tasks

5629B0B9ED6B4F49BE4B4B2D087652AC.description: Writes commas between items in an enumeration

C86600060EDF4875A1CAA81711754006.description: Writes a sentence with a capital letter at the beginning and a period or question mark at the end

9DDA14F59E08452E9F7764FBE8200192.description: Uses knowledge of capital letters, periods, questions marks, and commas between items in an enumeration to construct meaning of texts

8615940852124AF5B17FACB3799291DD.description: Uses intonation and pronunciation that can be understood by an English speaker

8DB1FB9442454380B3CF1897C2D6AA8D.description: Intonation and pronunciation for the functional language frequently used in class

63AD6EF93A144E85A8B75B94CF79A7C4.description: Uses verb tenses targeted for tasks

AE1D00B4F2564EF4AE5740651F73D545.description: Uses knowledge of verb tenses to construct meaning (e.g. imperative, past, future)

4796DF8A010540248CF7595DF5C3BCD0.description: Places articles before nouns (e.g. The bag is heavy. It’s a computer. She’s an athlete.)

AB042F88401541D5903E758DCD33C01A.description: Uses irregular plurals frequently encountered in class (e.g. people, children, feet)

99448339B66445C48B78B641C30F1A63.description: Writes an “s” at the end of nouns for regular plurals (e.g. kayaks, oranges, toys)

7E24CA931E254EC49E49410CE7E2169F.description: Uses knowledge of regular and common irregular plurals to construct meaning

C86B3892A46249688FA586018B1889C8.description: Places adjectives before nouns (e.g. red car, beautiful day)

5FEEAA3727AE46D5B5277768F0004468.description: Forms simple sentences (e.g. I like apples. Emily can sing and dance. Bring your book.)

45145633BC5743AFA6B953425E927ED3.description: Uses knowledge of word order in simple sentences to construct meaning

2C67750177294B2ABA7E5A6D4211C36B.description: Perseveres despite not understanding everything listened to or read, without getting overly anxious

B977D828527D418DA48E27B7593A716B.description: Accepting not being able to understand everything listened to or read

E25673548A164E7D8682B9455810461E.description: Dares to use functional language frequently used in class to speak only English, in spite of making errors

A28802CFE1224E0CACF6D7623E474CD4.description: Works and learns with others; helps others

965541DAF0164A00A4BF20B43350F8D0.description: Looks for specific information in a text

28EADEB3E7FB4807BD2FE53ED5D5A9A3.description: Glances through a text quickly to get a general impression and overview of the content

D4426EB4326B42758EF3A3C74E050E75.description: Writes down relevant information in an organized way (e.g. T-chart, Venn diagram, story web)

BB7B865A3E3E41FDAD0D787A90422D41.description: Makes use of material resources (e.g. word and expression banks, graphic organizers, posters, checklists, quick references, books, thematic and visual dictionaries, information technology)

81E10F46283945E3AA094456731383A9.description: Makes use of human resources (e.g. teacher and peers)

308A33F8BBAF4B09AAE56067B9914CDD.description: Repeats and rehearses, regroups, integrates and assimilates frequently

BC314FA850DB43C8BE92A941FA18C8E9.description: Makes intelligent guesses based on all available cues such as context, cognates, known words and expressions, visual clues, contextual cues, intonation, patterns

9FE7B9C625434E7B9E49325FF1F36B7B.description: Foretells based on prior knowledge, topic, task at hand, title, pictures, glancing through a text

0E2FEF2292204B4C9CBBEA7A58F42E99.description: Draws on own background knowledge as a source of information

DA079FB478754C05BADDE86E5B0FED3E.description: Decides to concentrate on the right things

96E58EA9BAA746899D73F2362EE89E09.description: Asks oneself: What am I supposed to do? In what order? What resources do I need? What should I listen to or read? What should I say or write? How will I say it or write it?

8D31563BD92340BD8D2BF91B6B52141F.description: Reflects on what has been learned and how

A4B0A345ED6242EE8D9837917AFC5370.description: Selects and uses the appropriate strategies

D34DB713FD4A4DD8995BDA5386737A57.description: Questions the pronunciation of new words read or heard

8EE62B2E54B941558994D0B6527776B3.description: Makes up for the lack of a precise word or expression by substituting known words or expressions

AEF9B558BAB5429791FD979F965788EB.description: Requests speaker to repeat or explain

F24812D7FDA947B89BCD32C5DBD6429E.description: Buys time to think out a response

8144EC7FEF2241AC82775D64AD015A93.description: Responds to question words used in context (e.g. who, what, how)

A38314DA3A51472D8341E998322D46C0.description: Uses expressions of time frequently encountered in class (e.g. five minutes, in September, next summer

F4C49440E83745079237300EFD1AF165.description: Uses prepositions and location words required for tasks (e.g. at, beside, right)

C5C0BB2C225447F4900B53D59864D22F.description: Uses the names of colours and shapes frequently encountered in class

7FD2C6E9E9364307B68759A89477EF15.description: Uses cardinal and ordinal numbers frequently encountered in class

6725FA435CCC463F9E662A9EA5F61AF2.description: Uses the alphabet to spell words in context

919C8B759BD84941AE8E6F5C67D093E5.description: Uses personal pronouns and possessive forms in context to talk about others (e.g. Your book is on the desk. It’s his pencil.)

60CCDC929CDE4780856EAC85EB7F9B50.description: Uses personal pronouns and possessive forms in context to talk about self (e.g. I have my book. The pencil is mine.)

5F6E8F73008E4D608CCDE4CAB2C70ACC.description: Uses targeted vocabulary to carry out tasks

734C24F150E643349B4987507029C9F6.description: Theme-related (e.g. family, sports, pastimes, food, animals, clothing, special events)

36475E0B7B15420EAAB31CF821A92FB1.description: Uses vocabulary related to other familiar environments (e.g. living room, grocery store, park)

9EB606ED76FC4500B3E6782A1480A727.description: Uses vocabulary related to school (e.g. pencils, classroom, schoolyard, teacher)

0B7C2AED974F4A318A294453B618B6F9.description: Uses action words (e.g. look, play, bring, draw)

8210870D88B9443F8AD985DB7D7F9A72.description: Action words frequently used in class

F6E1690010BD48F5BF2A343B8F6007BF.description: Contributes to teamwork (e.g. Each our turn. Do you have all your things? Five minutes left.)

723FB6ECDC724570855208C5E709E472.description: Contributes in creating harmonious exchanges (e.g. That’s a good idea. Let’s listen to Sophie. What a team. )

3FE90CB66F6B490FAD6942B3B1148DD3.description: Expressions promoting harmonious exchanges and teamwork

3FC167B58C524D2BA04030910D908CFD.description: Maintains exchanges (e.g. It’s your turn. What about you? Is that right?)

15E7C71193A84485B69B50055A271437.description: Invites (e.g. Do you want to play with us at recess? Would you like to work with me?)

E12B4B1D615B411DAF0A85C233D7B79D.description: Makes suggestions (e.g. Let’s be partners. How about making a poster?)

512E0EF177E2458E98C21D6AF944F670.description: Takes leave (e.g. Good bye. See you later. Have a nice weekend.)

BACAD11FBDF64D808CCD69E7FA6F9962.description: Uses basic expressions of courtesy (e.g. How are you? You’re welcome.)

F62EAA61DE8E463E978121A309B16D51.description: Expressions of courtesy and social conventions

52C2B70C50694460A85FF0A7528DBE08.description: Inquires about others’ feelings, interests, tastes, preferences (e.g. Are you okay? Who’s your favourite singer? What do you prefer?)

9A5DF7E1DD0B418BB20581BCA23A2959.description: Expresses others’ feelings, interests, tastes, preferences (e.g. He’s excited. My sister doesn’t like rock music. They prefer pizza.)

34820DFC68CF4C4394893ED93CBBE0A3.description: Expresses own feelings, interests, tastes, preferences (e.g. I’m happy. I like baseball. My favourite flavour is chocolate.)

73C7A2E6D38F4A839E077385EBC14CE6.description: Gives warnings (e.g. Careful! Watch out! Stop!)

488DA5BE165A40F8A18D1BCFD1719FD8.description: Inquires about others’ needs and wants (e.g. What does he need? What do you want?)

188D48D44844464297CAD85A62BFFC91.description: Expresses others’ needs and wants (e.g. He needs a ruler. She wants a new bike.)

B844BAB998B1426088CA38333A8E4F53.description: Expresses personal needs and wants (e.g. I need a pencil. I want a new skateboard.)

AE0CCBF9D05C4D4390E0977A68195E90.description: Accepts or declines offers of assistance (e.g. Sure. I’m okay.)

EB7F9A76008E4CA9AED709AFF5F83832.description: Offers assistance (e.g. Can I help you? Let me help.)

7A02185769784BCEAFC8E626BA155FBB.description: Asks for permission (e.g. May I go to the washroom? Can I borrow a pencil?)

C6C4C78310724A2C99F56907A93333C5.description: Inquires about others’ opinions (e.g. What do you think? What’s your opinion? What does he think?)

3723FB6F2A124189AAF40A3E34FD8EB7.description: Gives opinions (e.g. I think that…, I believe that…)

38796BA8A4D041B1A2A8B4C1387F73C9.description: Inquires about agreement/disagreement (e.g. Do you agree? Is this okay? Does she disagree?)

77340F2742264E959923D7D55DF0B962.description: Expresses agreement/disagreement (e.g. That’s right. I agree. I don’t agree.)

BE556AEC8AC8405793C75BA4562264CA.description: Asks yes/no questions (e.g. Do you have a pencil? Is this your book? Does he play hockey?)

4F25264CFF974D78B04804FDF447A82C.description: Asks W-questions (e.g. What page is it on? When is recess? Who’s your partner?)

78933D5346E84C33B6D3C28101BC166F.description: Inquires about others’ capabilities (e.g. Can you stand on your head? Are you good at math?)

954FC7DE60B54D49ABB5D83D7E0BCD67.description: States others’ capabilities (e.g. He can’t sing. She’s good at drawing. They can run fast.)

E1B6490C58EE4CF7B3B5B5F03A46FF7E.description: States own capabilities (e.g. I can play the guitar. I’m good at juggling.)

88F5979D379345F0BA7A3C3F51969B84.description: Inquires about basic characteristics of people, animals, objects, places (e.g. Does he wear glasses? Is it round? What colour is it?)

4B83866E7E2744938BFCAD8BFA95BC14.description: Describes basic characteristics of people, animals, objects, places (e.g. She is tall. It is round. It’s a big house.)

DDEF8DDBEE854ABCB9110280476020A5.description: Asks for identification (e.g. What’s this? What’s your name? Where does he live?)

A157B77B72904F669425C4A942696AAD.description: Identifies people, animals, objects, places (e.g. I’m a hockey player. This is my sister. It’s a polar bear.)

E3E9E1BE259A48CC896D5086AFB517CF.description: Asks for clarification (e.g. I don’t understand. Can you repeat? What do you mean?)

E6141A56623F4BE5B97149635BD70E0F.description: Asks for help (e.g. Can you help me? I have a problem. How do you say…?)

7C77C07D35AF4A43BB487604E6D1E434.description: Stalls for time (e.g. Wait a minute. I’m not ready. Let me think.)

E9205DDC1ED144E68ECD45E4115074CF.description: Gives instructions (e.g. Roll the dice. Pick a card.)

59DF172545D44E12858DDBBBD5C366CF.description: Participates in classroom routines (e.g. Teacher: “What’s the date?” Student: “It’s April second.” Teacher: “What is the weather today?” Student: “It’s sunny.” Teacher: “Open your binder.” Student: “I forgot my binder.”)
